column3: Please add a line or two about Trivial tree?\n
ACK, thanks for writing this up\n
ACK, very well written!\n
ACK, very nice!\n

@paveljanik Re: the trivial tree, maybe @theuni could comment on that. I think it was a great idea, but AFAIK it has not been kept up to date regularly lately, so I 'm not sure what his stance on it is now.\n
If it is so, I think that adding `[Trivial]` to pull request titles is enough to solve this.\n
ACK.\nNice work!\n
Nice work. Definite improvement on the developer-notes, which were somewhat hidden away. The fact that this is shown as suggested reading to everyone opening a pull request is also good.\n
Nit: Remove `-`.\n
Nit: Should "Nit" be included in this list?\n

I'm not sure if this is a good idea. Git and Github are two separate things. I agree with referencing a fix by `fixes #4321` placed in a _Github_ PR description or a _Github_ comment. Placing it in a _git commit_ is not required and not best practice IMO.\n
+1. I prefer to place it somewhere in the GitHub PR description.\n
Agree, to the extent possible you should be able to read and understand the\ncommits without needing access to the github repository or its PRs/issues.\n

Absolutely, it must be understandable without referring to them, but please **do** refer to solved github issues in the commit descriptions. This makes it much easier to keep track of what was solved when when browsing history.\n
s/proposal/proposals\n
s/diff/diffs\n
Should "fixed spelling" be the example we give as a good simple commit message? Maybe "Correct typo in xx.cpp", or something similar?\n
s/markdown to the /markdown in the/\n
s/time for required/time required/\n
Suggest rewriting this slightly\n*that the quality of the patch meets the minimum standards for inclusion, as well as\n
s/be unit test/be a unit test/\n
s/peer review is/peer review which is/\n
s/hierarchy/roles/\n

Prefer colon format (and seems to be more common):

```
p2p: Add ZMQ message support
consensus: Add new opcode for BIP-XXXX
qt/wallet: Refactor send code
```

(also note ZMQ really has nothing to do with p2p..)
Should I reopen TBC support? ;)\n

libsecp256k1*

Although I'm not sure this document should apply to it.
This doesn't belong under "must".\n
Also needs non-trivial miner support (for new rules) or community consensus (for removed/changed rules).\n
Not all good NACK reasons are technical.\n
s/repositories/repository/\n

"remembering [that] mistakes" or "keeping in mind that" perhaps?  

Good work :)
I'm sure there are some exceptions, but in general they should aim to be.\n
absolutely. They are a wholly different animal from normal run-of-the-mill changes, that should be made clear.\n
